description: Adjective and noun from Middle English drye, dryge, drüȝe, from Old English drȳġe (“dry; parched, withered”), from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz, *draugiz (“dry, hard”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“to strengthen; become hard”), from *dʰer- (“to hold, support”).

Verb from Middle English drien, from Old English drȳġan (“to dry”), from Proto-West Germanic *drūgijan, from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz (“hard, desiccated, dry”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“strong, hard, solid”).

adjectives.description: Adjective and noun from Middle English drye, dryge, drüȝe, from Old English drȳġe (“dry; parched, withered”), from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz, *draugiz (“dry, hard”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“to strengthen; become hard”), from *dʰer- (“to hold, support”). Verb from Middle English drien, from Old English drȳġan (“to dry”), from Proto-West Germanic *drūgijan, from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz (“hard, desiccated, dry”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“strong, hard, solid”).
dry (comparative drier or dryer, superlative driest or dryest)

entries.meaning: Free from or lacking moisture.
examples: This towel's dry. Could you wet it and cover the chicken so it doesn't go dry as it cooks?

entries.meaning: Unable to produce a liquid, as water, (petrochemistry) oil, or (farming) milk.
examples: This well is as dry as that cow.

entries.meaning: (masonry) Built without or lacking mortar.
(chemistry) Anhydrous: free from or lacking water in any state, regardless of the presence of other liquids.
(figurative) Athirst, eager.
Free from or lacking alcohol or alcoholic beverages.
examples: Of course it's a dry house. He was an alcoholic but he's been dry for almost a year now.

entries.meaning: (law) Describing an area where sales of alcoholic or strong alcoholic beverages are banned.
examples: You'll have to drive out of this dry county to find any liquor.

definitionGroups.group: Free from or lacking embellishment or sweetness, particularly:

entries.meaning: (wine and other alcoholic beverages, ginger ale) Low in sugar; lacking sugar; unsweetened.
examples: Proper martinis are made with London dry gin and dry vermouth.

entries.meaning: (humor) Amusing without showing amusement.
examples: Steven Wright has a deadpan delivery, Norm Macdonald has a dry sense of humor, and Oscar Wilde had a dry wit.

entries.meaning: Lacking interest, boring.
examples: A dry lecture may require the professor to bring a water gun in order to keep the students' attention.

entries.meaning: (fine arts) Exhibiting precise execution lacking delicate contours or soft transitions of color.
(aviation) Not using afterburners or water injection for increased thrust.
examples: This fighter jet's engine has a maximum dry thrust of 200 kilonewtons.

entries.meaning: (sciences, somewhat derogatory) Involving computations rather than work with biological or chemical matter.
(of a sound recording) Free from applied audio effects (especially reverb).

definitionGroups.group: Without a usual complement or consummation; impotent.

entries.meaning: Of a bite from an animal: not containing the usual venom.
(Christianity) Of a mass, service, or rite: involving neither consecration nor communion.
The process by which something is dried.
examples: This towel is still damp: I think it needs another dry.

entries.meaning: (US) A prohibitionist (of alcoholic beverages).
examples: The drys were as unhappy with the second part of the speech as the wets were with the first half.

entries.meaning: An area with little or no rain, or sheltered from it.
examples: Come under my umbrella and keep in the dry.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Australia, with "the") The dry season.
examples: […]  one was sodden to the bone and mildewed to the marrow and moved to pray  […]  for that which formerly he had cursed—the Dry! the good old Dry—when the grasses yellowed, browned, dried to tinder, burst into spontaneous flame—  […]

entries.meaning: (Australia) An area of waterless country.
Unsweetened ginger ale; dry ginger.
examples: All day, all night you feel as if the Earth could fly/Three more all for fine Indian Gin and whiskey dry.

entries.meaning: (Britain, UK politics) A radical or hard-line Conservative; especially, one who supported the policies of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the 1980s.

verbs.description: Adjective and noun from Middle English drye, dryge, drüȝe, from Old English drȳġe (“dry; parched, withered”), from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz, *draugiz (“dry, hard”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“to strengthen; become hard”), from *dʰer- (“to hold, support”). Verb from Middle English drien, from Old English drȳġan (“to dry”), from Proto-West Germanic *drūgijan, from Proto-Germanic *drūgiz (“hard, desiccated, dry”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerǵʰ- (“strong, hard, solid”).
dry (third-person singular simple present dries, present participle drying, simple past and past participle dried)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lose moisture.
examples: The clothes dried on the line.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove moisture from.
examples: Devin dried her eyes with a handkerchief.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To exhaust; to cause to run dry.
(intransitive, informal) For an actor to forget his or her lines while performing.
examples: An actor never stumbled over his lines, he “fluffed”; he never forgot his dialogue, he “dried.”
